question_text: A 61-year-old man with obesity has a 5-year history of near daily gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms. An upper endoscopy is performed.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is Barrett esophagus (Option A), which is defined as the extension of the metaplastic columnar epithelium above the gastroesophageal junction into the esophagus. Endoscopically, Barrett esophagus appears as salmon-colored mucosa compared with the normal pink-colored squamous mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Barrett esophagus is a consequence of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), even in patients who experience no clinical symptoms, and is classified as a premalignant condition because it has the potential to progress to esophageal cancer. Risk factors associated with Barrett esophagus include chronic GERD (â‰¥5 years), age older than age 50 years, male sex, White race, tobacco use, obesity, and a history of Barrett esophagus or esophageal adenocarcinoma in a first-degree relative.
